parts_of_speech.definition: To exist or occur; to have a state or quality

words.notes: The most fundamental verb in English. 'Be' changes form based on subject and tense (am, is, are, was, were, been, being). In Arabic, the present tense often omits the equivalent verb (أنا طالب = I am a student), but it's always explicit in English. Essential for describing identity, location, states, and forming continuous tenses.

parts_of_speech.definition: To possess, own, or hold something

words.notes: A versatile verb with multiple meanings. As a main verb, it indicates possession (لديه). As an auxiliary verb, it forms perfect tenses ('have done' = فعل). 'Have to' expresses obligation (يجب). Changes to 'has' with third person singular (he/she/it). Very common in daily English conversation.

parts_of_speech.definition: To perform an action or activity

words.notes: Functions both as a main verb (to perform) and auxiliary verb. As auxiliary, it forms questions and negatives in simple tenses. Changes to 'does' for he/she/it in present tense. Common phrase 'How do you do?' is a formal greeting. Notice how Arabic doesn't have a direct equivalent for auxiliary 'do' in questions.

parts_of_speech.definition: To speak words; to express something verbally

words.notes: Often confused with 'tell', but 'say' focuses on the words spoken, while 'tell' focuses on the person being told. Use 'say' when reporting exact words or general statements. Past tense is 'said' (irregular). Common in reported speech: 'He said that...' Notice it's used for both spoken and written communication.

parts_of_speech.definition: To move from one place to another; to travel

words.notes: One of the most common verbs of movement. Past tense 'went' is completely irregular. 'Go' appears in many phrases: 'go shopping', 'go swimming' (activities), 'go crazy' (become), 'go well' (proceed). Often paired with prepositions: go to, go in, go out, go up. The continuous form 'going to' expresses future plans.

parts_of_speech.definition: To obtain, receive, or become

words.notes: Extremely versatile and informal. Has many meanings depending on context: receive (يحصل على), become (يصبح), understand (يفهم), arrive (يصل), fetch (يحضر). Very common in spoken English. Past tense 'got', past participle 'gotten' (US) or 'got' (UK). Appears in phrasal verbs: get up, get out, get on.

parts_of_speech.definition: To create, produce, or cause something

words.notes: Often confused with 'do'. Use 'make' for creating/producing things (make food, make a plan) and 'do' for activities (do homework, do work). 'Make' is used with many nouns: make a mistake, make friends, make a decision. In Arabic, different verbs are used depending on context (يصنع، يعد، يجعل، يكسب).

parts_of_speech.definition: To have information or be aware of something

words.notes: A stative verb (not usually used in continuous form). Don't say 'I am knowing' - say 'I know'. Use 'know' for facts, information, and people you're familiar with. Past tense 'knew', past participle 'known'. Common phrases: 'I don't know', 'You know what?', 'as far as I know'.

parts_of_speech.definition: To use your mind to form ideas or opinions

words.notes: Used for mental processes, opinions, and beliefs. Can be stative (I think he's nice = opinion) or active (I'm thinking about it = active mental process). Past tense 'thought'. Common phrases: 'I think so', 'I don't think so', 'What do you think?'. Often softens statements to sound less direct.

parts_of_speech.definition: To get hold of something and carry or move it

words.notes: Very common with multiple meanings: physically moving something (يأخذ), requiring time (يستغرق), using transport (يستقل), capturing images (يلتقط). Past tense 'took', past participle 'taken'. Many fixed phrases: take a shower, take a break, take care, take place. Often paired with 'bring' (bring here, take there).

parts_of_speech.definition: To perceive with the eyes; to understand

words.notes: Not used in continuous form for physical sight ('I see' not 'I am seeing'), except when meaning 'meeting someone' (I'm seeing her tomorrow). Past tense 'saw', past participle 'seen'. Different from 'look at' (intentional) and 'watch' (for moving things). Common: 'see you later', 'I see' (I understand).

parts_of_speech.definition: To move toward or arrive at a place

words.notes: Opposite of 'go'. 'Come' indicates movement toward the speaker or reference point, while 'go' indicates movement away. Past tense 'came', past participle 'come'. Common phrases: come on (encouragement), come from (origin), come back (return). Used for both physical and abstract arrival.

parts_of_speech.definition: To desire or wish for something

words.notes: Stative verb expressing desire or need. Followed by noun (want food) or infinitive (want to go). More direct than 'would like' which is more polite. Not usually used in continuous form. In questions, 'Do you want...?' is common but can sound abrupt; 'Would you like...?' is more polite.

parts_of_speech.definition: To transfer something to someone

words.notes: Takes two objects: give someone something or give something to someone. Past tense 'gave', past participle 'given'. Used for both concrete items and abstract concepts (give permission, give advice, give a speech). Many phrasal verbs: give up (quit), give in (surrender), give away (donate).

parts_of_speech.definition: To employ something for a purpose
The act of using something; purpose or function

words.notes: As a verb, pronunciation is /juːz/ (like 'yooz'). As a noun, /juːs/ (like 'yoos'). 'Used to' expresses past habits (كان). Don't confuse with 'be used to' (معتاد على) meaning familiar with. Common phrase: 'it's no use' meaning pointless. The noun often appears in 'make use of' and 'of use'.

parts_of_speech.definition: To discover or locate something

words.notes: Past tense and past participle both 'found' (irregular). Often used with 'out' to mean discover information (find out = يكتشف). 'Find it + adjective' expresses opinion (I find it interesting). Different from 'look for' which is the action of searching. Commonly used: 'find time', 'find a way', 'find yourself' (discover your identity).

parts_of_speech.definition: To communicate information to someone

words.notes: Different from 'say': 'tell' focuses on the person receiving information and often includes them in the sentence (tell someone something). 'Say' focuses on the words. Past tense 'told'. Common phrases: tell a story, tell a lie, tell the truth, tell the difference. 'Tell' + person + infinitive gives commands (tell him to go).

parts_of_speech.definition: To do a job or be employed; to function
A job or task; the place where you work

examples.sentence: I have a lot of {work} to do.

words.notes: As uncountable noun, 'work' means tasks or employment (no 's' for plural). As countable, 'works' means artistic creations or factories. The verb means both to be employed and to function. 'At work' means at your workplace. Many collocations: hard work, homework, work out (exercise or solve).

parts_of_speech.definition: To telephone; to shout or say loudly
A telephone conversation; a shout

words.notes: Very versatile word. Main meanings: telephone (يتصل), shout (ينادي), name (يسمي). As noun, refers to phone call or a cry/shout. Common phrases: call back (return a call), call for (require), call off (cancel), phone call, wake-up call. In Arabic, different verbs used for different meanings.

parts_of_speech.definition: The indefinite continued progress of existence
To measure or record duration; to schedule

words.notes: Uncountable when referring to time in general (time flies), countable when referring to instances (three times). Many expressions: in time (before deadline), on time (punctual), at the same time, all the time, from time to time. As verb, usually means to measure duration or choose the right moment.

parts_of_speech.definition: To direct your eyes toward something
An act of looking; appearance

examples.sentence: I don't like the {look} of this.

words.notes: Different from 'see' and 'watch'. 'Look' is active/intentional (ينظر), 'see' is passive (يرى), 'watch' is for moving things (يشاهد). Many phrasal verbs: look for (search), look after (care for), look forward to (anticipate). 'Look + adjective' describes appearance (look happy, look beautiful).

parts_of_speech.definition: A method or manner of doing something; a path

examples.sentence: This is the best {way} to learn.
Is this the {way} to the station?
She has her own {way} of thinking.

words.notes: Multiple related meanings: method (طريقة), route (طريق), direction (اتجاه), manner (أسلوب). Very common in expressions: by the way (بالمناسبة), in a way (بطريقة ما), no way (مستحيل), on the way (في الطريق), give way (يتنازل). Often used with prepositions: in this way, on my way.

parts_of_speech.definition: Human beings in general or considered collectively

words.notes: Plural form, but doesn't end in 's'. Singular is 'person'. Takes plural verb (People are..., not People is...). 'People' as 'شعب' refers to a nation. When counting individuals, use 'person': three people, one person. Don't say 'peoples' except in rare contexts about ethnic groups.

parts_of_speech.definition: Of high quality; morally right; pleasant
That which is morally right; benefit

examples.sentence: He did it for the {good} of everyone.

words.notes: Very common adjective. Comparative is 'better', superlative 'best' (irregular). 'Good' is adjective (describes nouns), 'well' is adverb (describes verbs). Say 'He speaks well' not 'He speaks good'. Many expressions: good morning, good luck, for good (permanently), as good as (almost).

parts_of_speech.definition: Recently made or created; not existing before

words.notes: Opposite of 'old'. Can mean recently made, recently purchased, recently arrived, or unfamiliar. 'New to' means inexperienced with something. Be careful with pronunciation: sounds like 'noo' not 'nue'. Common phrases: brand new (completely new), what's new? (what's happening?), Happy New Year!

parts_of_speech.definition: A 24-hour period; the time when it is light

examples.sentence: In my father's {day}, things were different.

words.notes: Can mean a 24-hour period (يوم), only the light part (نهار), or an era/period (عهد، زمن). Days of the week are capitalized in English (Monday, Tuesday). Common expressions: day by day (تدريجياً), these days (في هذه الأيام), someday (يوماً ما), all day long (طوال اليوم).

parts_of_speech.definition: A period of 365 days (or 366 in a leap year)

words.notes: Plural 'years'. Used with numbers and age: three years old, in five years. 'Year' without article often refers to academic/school year (next year = العام القادم). Common: New Year, year by year, all year round, leap year. In Arabic, both سنة and عام are used, with slight differences in formal vs. colloquial contexts.

parts_of_speech.definition: Coming before all others in order or importance

examples.sentence: This is my {first} day at work.

parts_of_speech.definition: Before anything else; for the first time

words.notes: Ordinal number (unlike 'one' which is cardinal). As adjective, describes order or importance. As adverb, means before other things. Common phrases: first of all (قبل كل شيء), at first (في البداية), first aid (إسعافات أولية), first class (درجة أولى). Often paired with 'last'.

parts_of_speech.definition: An object, fact, or matter; anything that exists or is thought about

words.notes: Very general word that can refer to any object, idea, situation, or matter. Often used when you don't want to be specific or don't know the exact name. Common expressions: the thing is... (المشكلة هي), first thing (أول شيء), among other things (من بين أشياء أخرى), things like that (أشياء مثل ذلك).

parts_of_speech.definition: An adult male human; humanity in general

examples.sentence: The evolution of {man} took millions of years.
He is a {man} of his word.

words.notes: Plural is 'men' (irregular). Can mean an adult male specifically (رجل) or mankind/humanity in general (الإنسان), though this usage is becoming dated. Opposite is 'woman'. In modern usage, 'humanity' or 'people' is preferred over 'man' when referring to all humans. Common: young man, old man, man-made.
